makers.displaydate: 1471–1528; born and died Nuremberg, Germany; active Venice, Italy, and Nuremburg
makers.displaymaker: Albrecht Dürer, 1471–1528; born and died Nuremberg, Germany; active Venice, Italy, and Nuremburg

texts.textentryhtml: In this, the largest of his engravings, Dürer illustrated the legend of Saint Eustace, a Roman soldier and hunter who encountered a stag bearing a small crucifix between his antlers. After the stag spoke to him in God’s voice—saying, "why pursuest thou me?"—Eustace converted to Christianity. Dürer rendered scenery and animals alike with such a profusion of detail that Eustace’s spiritual vision seems to encompass far more than the speaking stag. In achieving delicate nuances of texture and tone with his engraved line, Dürer deliberately rivaled the effects achieved by a painter’s brush.
texts.remarks: K1-3 rotation May 2019, K1-3 rotation April 2014
